messages: b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:37): Hixie: Chicken
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:38): Hixie: Chicken/egg problem, though isn't FF 3.5 supposed to have improved support for such microformats?
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:39): What's a real shame is that Google doesn't cull information from our business listings that are all in microformats.

c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:40): Hixie: if someone wants a parser to do something, build one. The reason adding to calendar (/subscribing in google calendar) is the big one is because it's what everyone wanted to build
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:40): building a microformats parser is pretty simple if you have a decent HTML parser available, which many languages do

b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:41): c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0: I think the issue is that web surfers that browse to the site aren't able to make use of the microformats due to not having any built in ability in the browser.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:42): You could write a plugin, but you're still excluding the vast majority of people that wouldn't be able to figure it out.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:42): b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd: NEVER build that kind of cruft into a browser. That's what extensions/userscripts/plugins/other things are for
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:42): In this case, just exporting an iCal file would be easier.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:43): That type of support should be built into IE.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:43): So include a link to export said iCal data from the microformats, or also output iCal (it's not hard)
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:43): I heartily disagree
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:43): Browsers have too much crap in them as it is
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:43): But you already said that support for it would be simple.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:44): I said building a parser to do something is simple... that doesn't mean it belongs native in the browser
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:44): The complaint was about behaviours
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:44): if you build it into the browser, it's still only going to be able to be added to a calendar unless you build another behaviour
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:45): and if you build another behaviour, just do it with existing tools

b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:45): A rather large percentage of the Internet has contact information and events built into web pages.  If those were all built as microformats, it'd make sense to build support in for the browser.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:45): It'd be like not including SVG support.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:46): I like the idea of SVG support being a plugin, actually, but that's a seperate matter
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:46): The point is that the original complaint was that there was only one obvious action
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:46): Where that action lives makes no difference
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:47): Ideally browsers would support all official web standards out of box, and microformats would gain some sort of official status.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:47): Ideally browsers would only be content rendering windows to hang plugin on, and there would be no such thing as "official status"
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:48): but we're never going to get there, so we work with what we have :)
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:48): HTML 4.01 is an official standard.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:48): One would hope it is supported by the browser.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:48): It's a W3C standard, and thus official for those who recognise their authority
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:49): Are you suggesting JavaScript be moved to a plugin?
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:49): One would hope that most user agents would process HTML by default, yes, but it need not be a feature of all of them, there's no rule about that
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:49): b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd: I'm suggesting *everything* be moved to a plugin
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:49): Modular designs rule
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:50): Fine, then include all of those plugins by default, including ones that support microformats.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:50): But I've already conceeded that people are too rooted in their ways to do that
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:50): b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd: sure, but that still doesn't solve the root problem Hixie brought up
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:51): If most users have browsers that support microformats, then that would solve the issue.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:51): The issue was that "supporting microformats" only means "let them add to a calendar"... ie, not enough actions/behaviours available
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:51): Oh wait, I think I see what might be being said.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:52): Yeah, I see that now.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:52): But I fail to see the point.

c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:53): As do I... adding to calendar seems to be all people care about (as evidenced by it being all they've built)...  I've been working on a good "invite others" action as well (bookmarklet), not done yet

b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:54): Reading the microformat and getting an iCal file would be functionally identical, and that is the purpose.  If they want to "interact" with the event then they just need to add a form and maybe publish an API if someone wants to write an application for it.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:54): Ala, writing a Facebook application.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:56): I guess someone could suggest adding a tag to indicate that the Microformat fields are empty and are meant to be filled in by the client.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:56): b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd: microformats are kind of for data... not forms
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:57): empty ones are not so useful
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:57): Like creating a form with everything tagged as an hCal, and at the root have class="userSubmit" or something.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:57): Then an application could automatically find a form and fill data in to the proper fields automatically.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:58): But I'm still not seeing how that would be useful in any practical sense.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:58): better idea: use the class names from microformat be used as the name= attribute on the form (I tend to do this anyway)
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:58): more semantic, and acheives the same goal
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:59): Someone would need to specify then that form elements MUST not be scrubbed for data.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (10:59): That could be problematic.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (10:59): http://pastie.org/467373

b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:00): I suppose you could have a plugin that lets you fill in contact or calender information always using the exact same looking interface, and then that filled in form.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:01): What if someone assigns a value to one of those form fields?  How do you make sure a microformat plugin doesn't think that is a contact?

c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (11:02): b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd: a microformat plugin won't see it, because the class names aren't set to anything microformatty (or anything at all in this case)
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:03): It would actually be nice to be able to automatically fill in all contact fields in a form.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:03): slaps forehead.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:03): You're right.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:04): I think we still come back to the issue of "What's the point?"
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (11:04): Quite possibly
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (11:04): Although: 03:59 < b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd> It would actually be nice to be able to automatically fill in all contact fields in a form.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:05): And that is the only use I can think of.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:05): That doesn't even apply to a calender.
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (11:05): True. Not sure if there's a calendar use case
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (11:05): Except that standard field names are nice
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:06): It seems like a lot of work to go through too for a minute or two of saved time every so often.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:06): Yeah, standard field names are nice.
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:07): Anything but this though.  http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc3106
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (11:08): heh, I agree, using existing field/class names (and short ones) is much nicer than inventing some namespaced new thing :)
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:08): Ecom_ShipTo_Telecom_Phone_Number?
b5ef00f170716a058ad31a979fb22efd (11:08): Seriously?
c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0 (11:09): yeah :P
